transcript.content: Heroes by David Bowie on Radio 2. I'm Ricky Gervais, with me Stephen Merchant.
Hello there, um, Happy New Year.
Happy New Year indeed, and uh, uh, uh, across from us, the little fella who presses the buttons because to be honest, we can't be bothered.
Yep.
Karl Pilkington.
How would you describe Karl Pilkington for people who didn't hear the show last week?
Um, for people who didn't hear the show, Karl is - and he won't mind me saying this, um, because he won't fully understand it -
One of the most stupid men I've ever met.
Steve laughs
Yes. Absolutely right.
Um, he has a perfectly round head.
Yeah.
I mean unbelievable. You can, you can see pictures of him; go to RickyGervais.com. We've put up some um photographs, just snapshots, and honestly his head looks like an egg.
It's not an issue, though, is it?
What?
We're on the radio. Doesn't matter.
He's just trying to get - you know, paint a picture for people, though, Karl. It's important.
In fact, I have painted a picture. You can go to the BBC website and you can, uh, I think you can win that. If someone hasn't already.
I think you can also, can you download it as wallpaper for your, uh, for your computer? You can. So if you want to see a cartoon representation of Karl, then there it is.
It's an original signed by me. I'm, it's not a Damien Hirst.
No, sure.
But it, I mean I think it's pretty accurate, Steve. You d- I mean, for people who can't see him. You can see a few - a real photo or the - that's uh Karl Pilkinton, one of the most stupid men alive.
Happy Christmas.
You know, some people still think that he's an invention.
I know.
He think - they thought that, that, that we invented him and we give him lines and stuff. As if we could do that. What, have we shaved his head as well?
Well look-
And made him live in Manchester for 20 years? It's...
For people who've not experienced Karl before, they'll hopefully there'll be plenty of Karl later in the show.
Well, actually, um, we've got Karl doing a sermon.
Brilliant.
For, um, the Church of England. It's be been requested, um, by the, the, the Church of England, which is unbelievable.
Yeah.

And I actually went and bought him a little Bible, right? He didn't have a Bible. I- he said, "The Bible's too heavy, it's got no pictures." So I bought him a children's Bible which is embarrassing, asking for that in Waterstones.
Yeah.
For a start. And um, even that was too much for him. He was going, "There's two hundred pages." I mean the writing, the letters, the font, was about, I'd say, half a centimetre high, right?
Yes. Yeah.
And, uh, uh, but, you've, you've read it, have you?
Karl clears his throat
I haven't read all of it. I just caught some of the highlights.
So you-
You only
Give it me the other day!
So we're doing the history of religion, are we? Um, coming up.
What do you mean?
Well - ugh. What do you mean, what do I mean?
No, I'm just doing a little taster. What... the problem was, right, last week-
What do you mean, a little taster? What, like, what, wha-
Just to give em some-
Are we trying to sell Bibles-
No, hang on-
It's the biggest sellling book in the world. They don't need it. I thought you were gonna do a message a, a New Year's message.
No, but it's kind of been forgotten about a little bit innnit?
Oh yeah.
Steve laughs
Because of Harry Potter and stuff like that.
Yeah you see the Bible these days, and goes, "What's that? What do you mean, the Bible?"
No, but I'm just saying, there's probably a, you know, a lot of people out there, who've go- sort of gone, "Ah, you know, it's an old book.
And once something's been around for a bit, you've br- you don't sort of visit it. It's like, uh-
Sorry, this isn't Harry Potter we're talking about. This is the Bible.
Yeah I know, but-
It's still very popular, Karl.
But there's films out, do you know what I mean-
Brilliant.
There's films that have been and gone and its like oh, no-one's talking about it any more, I won't bother.
So, you're, you're giving the Ch-, you're giving the Church of England a little bit of a boost?
Steve laughs
Well, you're laughing but it is Christmas.
Excellent.
Excellent, that coming up.
Now last week - can I just ask - last week, um, on the show, we were uh, talking about the gift that you'd arranged to, uh, for your girlfriend. Now-
How long have you been going out with her again?
Um... pft... think it's about eleven years.
Eleven years, the - your life

Partner. He got her, um, a a gift when he left, um, his old job, of a camera. He didn't even unwrap it. He just passed it on straight away. Like pass the parcel to his girlfriend. We were giving him some stick. Um everyone - about 90% of people phoning in saying you are a skinflint. It's awful. How did, how did it go down?
She loved it.
Did you tell her?
Did she, did she love it?
Yes, I - I think she liked it, yeah.
Okay.
I mean she, she didn't really have a go on it. I was playing about with it on Christmas Day.
Sure.
Brilliant.
Showing her how to use it and that. And said, you know. She's, she's paid
For a holiday for us to go away. I said take it on that, use it. She's loving it.
Did you tell her before you gave it to her that you'd got it as a, as a leaving gift for your previous job?
Yeah, just before. I mean I wasn't going to but because of last Saturday, you sort of put a bit of pressure on-
Sure.
-and stuff, and-
Ricky snorts
-I went off and bought her a watch.
Nice.
Good!
But I thought a little extra- extra present.
One of those ones with a little calculator on? From, from a Texaco?
Uh. No, it's alright. It's like a little square art deco, the fella said it was.
It is nice. I've seen it.
Alright.
Yeah yeah yeah, no, it's, it is uh -
And how did you tell her? When you, when you came in with the big news?
What, about the camera?
That you hadn't bought the gift.
I just sort of said, "Oh, you said you wanted a camera, didn't you
Well here's one I got from work. And, uh, anyway, here's another one."
Steve laughs
Right
So I just sort of told her-
Fudged it.
-but moved on. Quick.
Brilliant.
It was fine.
And also, uh, you, you gave us the-
It was alright.
-devastating news last week that just before Christmas, your mum's budgie died. How was Christmas in your household? Was it-
Um... a little bit down. A little bit down. You know, with, with any death... it's always sad, innit. No matter what it is.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Particularly a budgie.
Well, I mean, how long she had it? Probably lasted about eight years or something, which is pretty good, innit, for a budgie?
Right.
Yeah, I think so.
Um, came unexpected. Wasn't ill. Um...
Steve laughs
Right.
And uh, what she, what, uh, I spoke to her the other day and I said, you know, how's it going? Because on Christmas Day she was down.
Yeah.

Been calling her up every day. And I spoke to her the other day and said, you know, how're things? And she said uh, said well the other bird that's in the cage - she's got uh, a sort of parrot that's in the same cage as it-
Right.
It's been a bit down.
Sure.
It's missing its mate. So what she did, she'd kept a few feathers from the budgeie that died, right. She got a rock, a couple
Of, uh, sandwich fasteners, and stuck the feathers on the rock. The other bird's happy now.
Wow.
Now I know that... your mother explains everything.
And if you ever die, we'll just get a tennis ball, stick it on the end of a broom. She'll be happy.
Ricky snickers

metadata.song_album: An Old Raincoat Won't Ever Let You Down

transcript.content: Rod Stewart - Handbags and Gladrags.
Handbags and Gladrags, by Rod Stewart. That'd make a good theme tune.
Brilliant.
Wouldn't it?
And then it would work really well, perhaps on a DVD.
Ricky laughs
Presumably, presumably that would
Still be available in the shops. Great for any, um, you know, new year's vouchers you've got.
You're listening to Ricky Gervais on Radio 2 with Steve Merchant and Karl Pilkington. So good Christmasses, yeah, all round?
Definitely for me. I had a great time. Yeah. Karl?
Uh... pfft... s'alright.
Steve laughs
How does it-
Nothing.
How does it rate-
Nothing excites him.
With, uh, what did Suzanne get you?
Um... she got me, uh- you see, you were having a go at me about giving her, uh, a camera, right? Which, which I think was-
Which was given to you.
No-
Which was second hand.
Doesn't matter that-
Essentially. second hand.
Doesn't, don't, don't really matter, that bit. But it's a present that both of us could use, right?
Mm.
And you were making me feel bad about that. And that's why I got her a watch.
Yeah.
Right. Which in a way I can use because I can say, "What time is it?"
Sure.
Steve laughs
But-
It's Chico time, innit?
But the thing is, right? She got me, a uh-
Not any more.
No.
She got me a, a little printer.
Oh yeah.
Brilliant.
That's good, yeah.
Well yeah...
You mean a little fellow who works in a print shop?
Just a little printer to go with a computer and that. But for me, again, that's a present that, you know, we can all be using.
You are so ungrateful.
It's not that!
It's just that, you know, when... it's good, when you're a kid, innit? When you- Christmas is all about, like, your present-
What did you want when you were a kid? What's your best present you ever had?
Um... There's a few things. I mean, one that, one that I always remember, one Christmas, right? Uh, it was the year when computers first came out, right?
Right.
And there was one called a Sinclair Spectrum that I wanted. Alright.
What year we talking? Eighty fff-
Must be eighty... eighty three, eighty four. Yeah.
Right, yeah.
And, uh
Anyway, I think me mam and dad's got me one. If, you know, it's under the tree in a big box and I'm thinking, "Yeah, that's about right."
Yeah.
About the size of a computer. Brilliant. Anyway, Christmas day comes, you know, I couldn't sleep and all that. Excited, like you are as a kid.
Yeah.
Get up, open it. It's not the one I wanted. Right?
Really?
It's not the Spectrum, it was a ZX81. Right?
Okay.
So I thought, well, I've, I've best not show that I'm disappointed and that. You know, even even as a kid you have, sort of, you know, that thing of saying-
You've lost that. Now you say, "Oh, it's not what I wanted, Suzanne." But go on, yeah.
Yeah yeah, but, but, you know. So,
Uh, so I sort of, you know, pretended I liked it and that. I thought, "Ugh, I'll just play some games on it, I'll just get on with it, right?"
Steve laughs
Anyway, I try and load-
Mature, even as a kid he had the weight of the world!
Yeah. It's a bind!
I know.
His parents have saved up for it.
He's - look at his frown lines! Look. He's frowned since he was about four.
Yeah.
Look at those lines.
Alright. So... yeah, but this is why. You'll understand in a minute when I tell you the end of this story.
Go on.
So I load up a computer game which... it used to take about ten minutes. Alright.
Was it on casette? You have to let it-
On casette.
Oh, yeah. You-
Yeah, it sounds like a fax machine, didn't it?
Yeah.
Yeah.
Right. Anyway, it wouldn't load.
Ugh.

I was thinking, what's up with this? Is it broke, right? And I kept trying it, and me dad sort of, 'e, 'e, me mam used to get up early to open the presents with me. Me dad got up at about midday, couldn't be bothered. Right?
Sure.
Anyway, he comes down, I-
This is so telling.
I know! This picture he paints is so heartbreaking!
I know. It's like Alan Bennett or something.
Yeah, right.
Yeah, or Dickens.
Yes, or one of those kind of 60s black and white- Like Kathy Come Home, sort of-
Ricky laughs
You know the really-
Yeah. [unintelligible] dramas.
So.
So, anyway, so I'm there, right? Get - frown, growing, and that.
Yeah.
Ricky laughs
Trying to read this book, thinking, "Why isn't it working?" So me dad has a
Look, and he goes, "Oh, you're missing a bit." And I said, "What?" He goes, "You need a ram pack."
Right.
Which is a bit that you put in the back of it that gives it extra memory.
Yeah.
So I'm like, what do you mean?
You need one of them.
Ricky snickers
Like... wha, what do you mean? It's, it's Christmas Day, right? And, and we're talking about the days when, like, Tandy wasn't open.
Sure.
It wasn't open for days.
Yeah,  yeah.
Tandy!
Do you know what I mean? It's like now, by lunchtime Christmas Day, everything's open.
Yeah, sure.
Yeah.
Right. Then, you had to wait about two weeks.
Steve laughs
Anyone like had a big holiday and everything.
Yeah.
So I'm like, "Oh, god. Oh. Oh."
I actually started to be sick, right?
Steve laughs
With frustration.
Oh no!
What?!
Well, I-
Actually, you were physically sick?
How old were you?
Do you know, like-
How old were you?
Well, like I say, I don't know. It must have been about... eight or something?
Oh.
But that thing of like, what, what, it's Christmas Day and I can't play with it. And I had to wait for like two weeks, what have you. Sat over the kitchen sink, sort of going-
Karl imitates being sick
Ricky explodes in laughter
Stress, stressing out.
Steve laughs
I hated it. It was a rubbish Christmas.
Oh!
Wow!
I love the idea of you going-
Ricky imitates being sick
Stress, innit.
What did your dad say?
He just sort of said, "Look, calm down. We'll get you one when the shops open." It was like yeah but-
Karl imitates being sick
Two weeks, innit!
Ricky laughs
I have never heard anyone being sick from stress.
Oh, poor little kid! He's so stressed.
Unknown song starts playing.

Before the track, we heard Feeder on Radio 2. Uh, Steve Merchant here with Ricky Gervais, Karl Pilkington. We were talking, uh, before that about, um, rotten gifts and particularly gifts that Karl's received in the past. We're just actually thinking now, because we've got to give away this - uh, we haven't GOT to give away, but we're generously giving away - a Eurhythmics platinum disc. So if you're a Eurythmics fan, or indeed if you're not but perhaps you know someone who is, and maybe you've got some, some rotten gifts for Christmas, then, uh, you can get in touch with us. Let us know what the the worst gift is that either you received this year or maybe even in the past. You know, something that really you just, just was terrible.

Or maybe you, like Karl, had the poker face when you received it. You politely opened the box, but inside you were dying. But you can get in touch with us, 882921, we've got the email gervais@bbc.co.uk or you can phone us 0500 288 291. The worst gift ever will receive the Eurhythmics platinum disc.
Well, uh, talking of gifts. Um, I got my, um, girlfriend, uh, a few gifts. Bought her a trip to, um, Paris and a few little bits and pieces, and one of which was a trip to the theatre.
Nice.
Um, a thing we'd walked past before
And we'd wanted to - look, looked really great. The, the Woman in Black-
Oh, okay.
-which is on at the Fortune Theatre in Covent Garden. I bought her four tickets so you know, we could, um, she could take some people. She chose to take, um, Karl and Suzanne.
Well of course, now I think it's, it's a scary play, isn't it? It's a spooky play.
It' a scary thing, it's about a ghost-
So you've got, instantly Karl's the man.

Absolutely. Um, and it was, it was, it was - wasn't it great? Wasn't it? And the theatre was so lovely and, uh, the production is, is so, so lush. And it's ge- it's genuinely really, rea- it's been going for seventeen years so they've really honed it and it's-
Yeah.
And it was great watching Karl. Um, uh, at one point, um... Uh, we were in a box, um, which I'll tell you about in a minute.
Right, yeah.

And, and I pointed, I just pointed to show Karl that this face was appearing, right? But as my, um, as I was pointing, he didn't see me pointing. My finger came into his peripheral vision and he went, "Argh!"
Steve laughs
And I laughed for about five minutes. Because he just saw a finger coming. I wasn't even trying to wind him up in that example.
Sure.
That was such a bonus for me.
Yeah.
And I nearly died. But

The reason we were in a box... I went there and I said, "Oh, can I um get a box?" And they said, "Oh the boxes are a little bit small and cramped." I went, "Okay," so give it give you some really good seats. So we got some nice seats downstairs. And, uh... do people go to the theatre these days to clear their throat?
Yeah.
And their nose?
Yeah.
Because I was surrounded by people going-
Ricky sniffs wetly
-which I find absolutely disgusting. I even - that even annoyed me, doing it, and I apologise for people at home, listening. And coughing and eating sweets.
Yeah.
Chatting about things.
Yeah.
Right. And I was,
I was, I was getting a bad neck, you know what I'm like.
Yeah.

With anything. I just wanted it to be silent, right. So, uh, in the interval I said, "Look," I went up to the manager and I said, "Ooh, can we go in a box?" and they went, "Uh yeah, fine. Yeah." It was free. They, they didn't sell it. So we went up there and they let us go in one. The first row- we have to go past some people in the interval, trailing past going, "Sorry. Sorry. Sorry." All, right.
"I'm a celebrity, I get a box."
Yeah, yeah, yeah, that's exactly - yeah.
Yeah yeah yeah.
So they probably think, "Oh, they've given it to him for special treatment."
Yeah.
I didn't buy it. It's no extra money.
Yeah yeah yeah. Yeah.
But they just didn't sell it because it was a-a- you know.
Another reason to hate you.
Yeah, exactly. Yeah. And
But we went in there and there's only three chairs. So I went, "Oh, oh this is, well, has the other box got four chairs?" Karl went, "I'm not going out there again."
Steve laughs
Right? I said, "We've gotta." He said, "I'll sit on the floor." Imagine him sitting on the floor.
Were you sat on the floor with your little head peeking over the edge of the box?
Well, no, no, this is it-,

So I went, "Oh, let's go." We went out. He was so embarrased. Course, everyone's going, "Oh look, they're coming past again." Walking past people again. Went in the box. Everyone's looking at the box, now.
Yeah.
Right. Um, and Karl was horrified. I- Karl was trying to hide, but it was-
To be honest, I mean, the idea of a box is you get a better view, but I didn't because I was like, "Ah. I'll have to sit right at the back."
Yeah.
I might as well have been, like, near the fire exit. I just was like, I don't, I don't want to be seen.

No, that's not the idea of boxes, to get a better view. I think it's from, uh, days where it was me- you were - how you were meant to be seen. The boxes face each other, right, and you're meant to see who's in the other box. It was very - a socialite type thing. The boxes are probably the worst view in the theatre. That's why some theatres don't actually sell them. But I'll tell you what, I'd rather have to lean forward and see summat than be surrounded by people chewing, and sniffing.
But it wasn't that bad though, Steve, that's the thing. You know what he's like?
Ah, well, yeah.
I mean anything that's meant to be
Like a nice relaxing night out, whether it's going for a nice quiet meal, suddenly turns into this, like, nightmare.
Well I won't go to public places with Ricky because there's always something that'll annoy him, and then he won't take it out on them, he'll take it out on you.
Yeah.
We gotta leave, we gotta leave, it's too smoky, it's too noisy, it's not noisy enough, there's music, there's not music. It's an absolute nightmare.
Well, people annoy me, that's what.

Stress, stressful. So, so and he - I mean just the other day, right? All went out for something to eat. Nice quiet, you know, Italian place. I walk in. There's about six people in there, having a nice quiet...
Yeah.
...meal.
You know, quiet, I thought, "Right, right that's good, he's not going to complain about the noise and that." Sit down. I have, uh, some arrabiata, which is nice and that.
Alright.
Anyway, 'e starts, uh, sort of normal chat, um, saying how he'd like to put me head in a vice.
Ricky explodes with laughter
Um...
He- sorry, he'd like to put your head in a vice?
In a vice. Yeah just-
Not really-
-sort of normal, sort of.
Yeah!
Yeah?
Yeah. And I f- Yeah, I was just thinking that it would be lovely to put him in what, you know, those vices that are sort of attached to work benches?
Yeah.
Just so - not to anything else -just put it in there so he's caught, so he's caught there.
Then I could sort of do what I want. Paint his head or summat.
Sure.
Or feel it squeezing. And I imagined, I just imagined, sort of squeezing it too tight-
So, so, so, he's saying all this right? Which, I'm getting the sort of picture enough-
Yeah.
-without sounds, right?
Right.
But then he thinks well, why not add sounds? It's quiet in here. Right. Starts sort of going, "So your head's in the vice, tighten it, and you're sort of going-"
Karl makes a noise like a strangled goose
Ricky laughs
Right? So he's sat in a chair, quiet restaurant, doing that. It's like the scene out of when 'Arry Met Sally.
Yeah, right.
All these, like, tourists and that sat there, sort of
Going, "Oh, Ricky Gervais over there." And suddenly, aright, from a look of, like, "Oh, that's good, it's Ricky Gervais" to "What the hell is going on?"
Steve laughs
But I just imagine his little head, he goes, "What are you doing?" I just imagine him and then tightening, I go-
Ricky makes a noise like a deranged parrot
Is there any other radio show that's ever been on Radio 2 that's had this discussion?
Well, no, I!
Does Johnnie Walker, OBE, ever say, "I'd love to put Terry Wogan's head in a vice and see what happens?"
It's... oh dear.
Unknown song

Eurythmics, Here Comes the Rain Again on Radio 2. We've got a Eurthymics platinum disc to give away and we'll uh get to that shortly. Uh, keep your worst Christmas gifts ever coming in. And you were talking about, Rick, about the, um, the er nightmarish people you find now in any kind of, you know, theatre or... and the cinema is- because I love the cinema, as you know, and I'm a big movie buff.
Yeah.

And for me, I feel that when I go into the cinema it should be the red carpet treatment. I go all the time, you know, I'm a big cinema fan, I shouldn't have to sit with, for want of a better word, the scum-
Yeah.
-of the world, do you know what I mean?
By scum you mean anyone who isn't you.
Anyone who isn't me.
Yeah yeah yeah yeah.

And uh, and uh... but sometimes you know, you end up going to the cinema, you know, on a Friday or a Saturday evening because you, you want to be, you know, you don't want to be a sad loner who goes on the Wednesday afternoon. So sometimes you're forced to sort of see these people. And I went to the cinema once to see- remember that film, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon?
Yeah.

And I sat there, I thought this is great. I was, nice big seat, it was fine. And this woman comes trundling in. She was huge. I mean, properly mammoth like the, um, the Marshmallow Monster at the end of Ghostbusters, do you know what I mean?
Ricky snickers
Kind of waddling in like that, with this tiny little flake of a husband.

And she had everything. She had nachos, hot dogs, big soft drink cartons, you know what I mean? It's like - you know those people who, they, they've gone out to eat and if- and they pop into the cinema and if a film happens to be showing, they'll, they'll go and watch that.
Brilliant.
Basically, they've come to eat.
They've gone for a picnic.
They've come to - yeah.
And there's a film on.
They've come to graze.
Yeah.

And, um, so they've arbitrarily chosen this film. So she's in there, the trailers come on. And it's not only is she greedy, but you can tell she's stupid. This trailer comes on for AI, remember that film, Spielberg film, AI?
Yeah.
And um, and that, the trailer is something like, uh, "Jimmy is a 12-year-old boy.

He doesn't, he feels like a human. He da da da. He experiences emotion like a human. But he's not a human. He's a *robot.* Right. And everyone goes quiet. And she went to her husband, "How old was he again?"
Oh!
So already, I'm, I'm f- ugh - my back's up, you know what I mean?
Oh.
Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon comes on, right? It comes up and, you know, it's, it's um, it's in Mandarin, I think.
Yeah.
It's a, it's an Asian film. And it comes up, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon. She says - bear in mind she's paid the money to come in - she says, "Funny name for a film!"
Ricky explodes with laughter
Which is... pretty weird. So, it comes up,

It says Mandarin subtitles, she goes, "It's not subtitles?!" It comes on, right, they're all speaking in Mandarin. She, to her husband, turns to him, she starts going, "Ching chang chong chong chang chang chong."
No!
"Ching chang chong chong ching ching ching." Like, during the film. I mean the film's starting and she's doing that. She's going, "Funny language! Wing wang chang yong wing ching chang chong chong."
Oh!
And they start both doing it, right?
Oh god.

So I get up, I'm so angry I want to make- but again, course, not- too polite to actually say anything. So I think I'll make it clear what my feelings are. So I get up, hoping that the seat will flip back loudly and I can stalk off.
Knock her popcorn all over her.
Yeah. All over his stupid face. But, um, sadly, the seats didn't flip up.
Aw.
So I just kind of huffily
Climbed over a few seats, sat down - ha, brilliant! - next to a teenaged girl, on her mobile phone.
Oh!
And she's on there, she's chatting away-
Steve does an impression of a teenaged girl on a phone

Da na na na na, "I'll meet you after," da da na na na. And I wanted to grab the phone off her and say, "I'll be honest with you, you're 14, and unless this is your broker in Hong Kong saying, 'The big deal is about to go through,' - which I suspect it's not; I suspect it's Gavin, saying, 'Can we meet behind the bike sheds later?' -
Ricky giggles
Put the phone down!" People who are on the phone in the cinema!
I know.
It drives- ugh.
I know. I can't, I
It drives me spare.
I cannot believe it. I cannot believe it. See, you're, you're, see you're like me.
But people always say, they always say, "Why do you get so angry? Your New Year's resolution
Should be calm down, chill out, you know." But, I- how can you chill out when this stuff's going on?
What's your... what's your New Year's resolution, Karl?
Well, well, no, just with that, though. I mean, surely people are allowed to, like, have a chat if a film's got subtitles?
Why?
Because you can read it. Doesn't matter about the noise or anything.
That is the most stupid thing I have ever heard in my life.
No I'm just saying, not-
I mean that really is the most stupid thing I've ever- so, go along with your iPod on.
Yeah, take a Ghetto Blaster.
Well... yeah, you could if you, if you can multitask. I mean, that would do my head in, having music and I don't wa - know what to sort of concentrate on. But
If you - it's only like reading a book when you're on a train, innit?
But what-WHAT?
You've got noise around you.
What are you talking about? These films cost millions of dollars. They're-everything's, everything's perfect, and they-
And the music, the sound effects-
The, the, the, the whole montage. The, this mixed medium- And someone comes along and goes, "Oh, I might as well talk to Gavin on my phone. We're reading it anyway." You're an idiot.
Alright.
You're an idiot, Karl. I think your New Year's resolution should be less stupid.
Nah, nah, I'm doing, uh - I'm going to try and learn something new every day
Through 2006.
What have you learnt today?
Uh, well I did a lot yesterday so I'm having a day off today.
Steve laughs
Ricky laughs
But, but, no, you know, just, uh, well, I did, didn't I? I did the, the, the Bible stuff and that. So, uh, I'm gonna...
Oh, yeah. We got that coming up. Karl's sermon.
What's your New Year resolution? To be less annoyed?
I suppose I should be more tolerant of others.
And do you know what Ricky said his is going to be?
What?
He's gonna be more annoying.
Yeah, well, I just thought, I just thought-
Ricky laughs
But this is the wonderful hypocrisy of it, because you, you've just been agreeing with me about how you hate people who are annoying. You-
But only to friends! People like - the thing is right, I've gotta, I've got to say a couple of things, right.
The reason I sort of torture Karl is because I-it-I don't know. My friends - I, I, I've got friends with defects.
Sure.
I don't know what... I, all my friends are slightly weird, or stupid, or something wrong with them. Karl's little round head. Uh, ju-ju-I mean, the brain of a fish.
Steve laughs
Yes.
Right? I can't keep my hands off his head. Um, Robin Ince. He's got glasses, he waddles funny, he's got little thumbs there - his thumbs are too short, right?
Sure.
I can't keep my hands off him, right? My mate, um, Rob, um, who did Flanimals with me, he's got a perfectly round head.
His teeth protrude slightly.
He is in America, though, for when you need a little round bald head, in' he? Just in case you're-
Yeah, exactly! For when I go to New York or- And he looks a bit like Dave Hill from Slade.
Interesting that you're collaborating on a book but he chooses to live in America.
Ricky laughs

I know, yeah! But um, could I just say also that I do not advocate the use of vices on friends' heads. It's dangerous, do not, do not, um, squeeze your mate's head in a vice. That's just between me and Karl and you know and, but-
Ricky Gervais is an experienced annoyer.
And he probably wouldn't let me do it, to be honest. I'd have to offer him an awful lot of money. Also, do not smoke. There's no point.
Mm hm.
And floss. I wish I'd flossed when I was a kid. Also, if you've got a bicycle or anything like that for Christmas, please wear the correct safety gear.
Well, whoa. Whoa whoa whoa whoa.
What?
Well, I got a bike as a kid.
Yeah.
Right. And my dad, uh, you know, he'd - I think, I think the helmets used to come, come with them, and what 'ave you. I popped it on, went out on me bike. Coming back into the garden.
Steve laughs
Dad sees me. He says, "Come here." I said, "What?" He said, "I never want to see you wearing that helmet again. You look ridiculous."
Ricky laughs
Neil Young - Heart of Gold
Oh, wow!
Oh! He'd rather take the risk!
No-one looks good in them though, do they?
I d- Yes,  they do. Wear the helmet.
Neil Young and Heart of Gold on uh, BBC Radio 2 with me, Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant-
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington.
Alright.

We were asking for the worst Christmas gifts you've ever received, uh, past or present, and uh, there have been some absolute stinkers here. Pete Archer says, "I'm diabetic and I once got three big tins of sweets."
Ricky snickers
I mean, that's just rubbing it in. Cesca says, uh, "I once got a Christmas tree from my brother. On Christmas Day."
Well that's...
Long-term present, innit.
Yeah.
Well, it depends.
What do you mean?
Was it a plastic one or a real one?
We need more information. "I got a Flymo from my 85-year-old gran, which was nice but for the fact that I live in a flat."
Ricky snickers
Well, he could do the carpet.
Steve laughs

Um, there's one here, it says, Syd from Leeds, he says, "I once received a PlayStation 2 which I really wanted. I didn't open it for a few hours while we had lunch, and I was looking forward to playing the game - bit like you with your ZX Spectrum.
Yeah.
I opened up the box and much to everyone else's enjoyment, there was two oranges and a pair of socks!"
That's cruel.
But that's like...! I mean, that's ju... what kind of a family is that?!
I mean, in Karl's case, he actually forgot to buy a ram pack.
Or... Harvest Festival, the vicar's got a PlayStation 2.
Steve laughs
Yeah.
It's just, it's just the wrong label, isn't it? Yeah, he couldn't believe his luck.
So-

Coming up, actually, talking of vicars... a lot of vicars listen, apparently, I don't know how many that is. I don't know how many there are. But um, uh, Karl's going to do a sermon. Um, you remember, um, last week, uh, he insulted vicars, saying they only work one day a week. Uh, he made a vicar swear.
Yeah.
Who said, um, "Maybe if I, um, give up my one day a week, I can
Become a DJ and do bugger all all week."  You made a vicar swear.
But I didn't - I didn't mean to. I just was-

No. Gillian Oliver's phoned in and she's the Press, um, uh Officer for the Church of England. And has invited Karl to do a, um, a sermon. We've risen to the challenge. Karl's gonna do a bit of a sermon. Can we just say - we've just - that's the one we've we picked on, we're open to all religions here.
Yeah.
Maybe, uh, in the future, Kyle can do a sermon, uh, for another denom-denomination.
Well...
I don't know, you know. Um...
Well do you... it just depends though. 'Ow, ow sort of thick the book is.
Right.
So you want a religion with a smaller book.
Just a smaller book and...
Can I just say, I view all religions equally-
Yeah.

-because I am an atheist. So I truly do view all religious beliefs equally. Um, but you know, just 'cause I don't believe in it... a lot of people do, and Karl is gonna basically sum up the Bible. That's what we're doing today, isn't it?
Shall we play a record and then come back with the first part of Karl's sermon?
I cannot- I, I mean, I, I honestly can't wait. I feel like squeezing his head during the show.
Do it, mate.
Okay.
The Rolling Stones - Waiting on a Friend
Can we get a vice?
Ricky snickers
Stones, Waiting on a Friend. Great track.
Amazing tune.
So, Karl. You've studied the Bible over the last couple of days.
Well.
And you're going to give us, uh, uh, basically, the Bible, abridged. Is that right? Just, uh, condensed. Um-
Er... Just, just that, you know, it's that time of the year when religion, you know how [unintelligible] you are and that.
Well, save it, let's just do a sermon. Everyone, everyone;s sittled - uh, settled down at home. Turn the radio up. This is, um, Reverend Karl Pilkington with, uh, the history of
The Bible.
Alright. Thank you very much. Right, well, uh, thanks for coming. Um. Starting off, you know, I mean, I started off at the beginning of the, of the book. What have you.
Ricky snickers
The Bible, we'll call it, for the sake of argument.
Right. Um... There's quite a bit missing. It doesn't, it doesn't say about how... sort of God was already about. So it doesn't go right back to the beginning. Um...
Steve laughs
Right, okay.
God, God's already knocking about and that.
Yep.
Anyway, he made the world, right. He does it
Did all that, right.
Yeah.
He sorted out, um, sort of sun, for, for in the day and that, so everything's light and you can see yourself about.
Steve laughs
Right.
He did the stars and the moon for at night, right. I was thinking about that. Uh, if I was him, I probaby would have just let it be day all the time rather than having two systems.
Well you're not criticising God?
No I'm not, I'm not, I'm not, I'm not having a go-
Okay.
I'm just saying- I mean it's easy, now, innit, in hindsight-
Steve laughs
-to sort of say, "Do you know what?"
Yeah.
It's easy for me to criticise him, but he was working blind, you know.
He sort of, he's sort of loosened the top but you've just got it off.
Yeah.
Yeah, sure, yeah.
Yeah, yeah.
He did a lot of the work. Yeah. Cheers.
No, I'm just saying though-
Yeah.

-like they mess about with the clocks and that because of farmers getting up in the dark and that. If it was day all the time, less crime and that. I'm just saying, it, it, it might have been worth an id- you know.
He missed a trick there is what you're saying.
But he moves in mysterious ways, so you don't know why he's done that. He might be...
Alright.
-he might be thinking something that your small brain can't really-
Fair enough.
Right.
I'm not having a go, like I say. I'm just, just reading it and thinking about it. That's what it's all about, innit?
Yeah. Absolutely, yeah.
Education. Get yourself thinking.
Absolutely, you know, yeah. Go on.
Right. Anyway, so  uh, he did all that, HE made the sun and that. And then he said,

"Oh, make some creatures and stuff." He made a load of birds, loads of different birds. Creatures. Animals and that. 'Cause with the world being so big... it's like if you buy a big house, you need more furniture, don't you?
Right.
So he made this and he was like, "Ah, for Go- what am I gonna fill it with?" So this is why he did all these animals.
Right. That's not actually in the Bible-
No, this is-
-you've just extrapolated there on the mind of God.
Yeah.
Well I'm sort of just treating it like it's his big house, innit?
Right.
And he's filling it, he's making it look nice. Different birds and what have you.
Yeah.
Right. Just my opinion.
He's making it sound like the Playboy Mansion.
Steve laughs
Yeah.
So, anyway, right, so, uh, he does all that. And, uh, he thinks right, I'll make a little man and a woman.
Sure.
Who we all know as like Adam and Eve.
Yeah.
Um, everyone knows them names but at no point is, is their surname mentioned.
Ricky laughs
Well he's not going to have trouble with the post.
Steve laughs
Right.
Is he?
So anyway, right, Adam and Eve are knocking about. Uh. God says to themm, "Look, just enjoy yourselves and that, right? Um, do what you want.
But I'll tell you this. I'm only telling you once," he said. He said, "Don't be eating fruit from that special tree.
Yeah.
So, they were like, "Alright, fair enough." He said, "The tree that I'm talking about is the Tree of Knowledge."
Yeah.
So that's sort of made it a little bit worse, because it sounds good and that. And you're like, "Ooh, knowledge."
Yeah.
Like, "Don't go in that door." Yeah, exactly, yeah.
Yeah it's that sort of thing. Instead of just sort of not telling them...
Mm.
Because I don't know... see, the, the Tree of Knowledge, what it had on it, by what I can work out, is...
It's an apple tree, right?
Ricky snickers
And it's pretty tempting, innit, to, to have a little cheeky apple. Because I don't, I don't know what they were eating back then.
Right.
Do you know what they were, what they were, what they were getting by on?
No. I don't, no.
Right, so anyway, so, they were like, "Yeah, right, whatever." Eve goes for a wander about.
Yeah.
Alright? Killing time and that.
Steve laughs
Bumps into this snake.
Oh yeah.
And, uh, snake said, uh, you know, it said, "Alright? Got an apple," alright? And, uh, he was selling it to her, he's going, "It tastes good and that." Right?
And she's like, "Well, shouldn't really but, you know. I've been told that I shouldn't eat that," because I think God said to her at some point, um-
Oh get on with it. You're on page one at the moment!
This is absurd, Karl. We've gotta just-
This is just unbelievable!
I know, but I'm just, just painting-
Just get to the point! You're on page one-
But-
-you haven't moved on. Just get-okay, we know Adam and Eve, what have you learnt?
Yeah, I know, but I'm just saying, he was saying, "Don't eat it because it's dangerous."
Yeah, I know, we know. Get on with it, just get on we- we- I mean, OH!
But the thing is people do eat things that are dangerous, don't they? Like them
Pufferfish. Even to this day, people are eating stuff that can kill 'em.
Yeah.

So it's not a threat. They're not, they're not that bothered. It's an apple, right. They're gonna have a little cheeky apple. Anyway, they eat it, right? God goes mental at 'em. He said, "I told you not to do that. I've told you can enjoy yourself and everything. You've, you've gone against what I said."
Ricky makes a noise of exasperation
"You've eaten the apple." Adam and Eve sort of got told off and what have you. They went off and had kids. Um, that added extra pressure. A lot of arguments happened-
Steve laughs
And, uh, that's, that's kind of part one.
That is amazing. That is amazing. So... oh, you're an idiot. Really, you are an idiot.
Well. Part two later then.
You'd better buck up your ideas in part two.

Lynyrd Skynyrd - Sweet Home Alabama
What a great track.
Amazing.
Lynyrd Skynyrd, Sweet Home Alabama on BBC Radio 2 with me, Steve Merchant-
Steve laughs
And me, Ricky Gervais.
And over there. Both of us.
Yeah.
Karl Pilkington.
Alright?
Um...
Still to come, we should also point out, we've got Rockbusters on the way. It's the, it's the quiz that's not sweeping the nation. No one cares.
Oh, no, that's not fair.
Well...
No, look at him. Look, he's probably been sweating over that. He's been reading a children's Bible.
Yeah.
But I mean and that's all he came up with: the first people were Adam and Eve.
Yeah.
I mean-
And we don't know what their surname is.
Unbelievable. What an idiot you are.
Also in the, in the third hour, Monkey News.
Yep.
Um, which I think we're all looking forward to.
It' sort of like Darwin- Darwinism versus creationism, isn't it? Monkey News, Adam and Eve.
Yeah.
Which do you like? Do you like Monkey News or do you like Adam and Eve?
Also it's probably worth um, kind of digesting some of the, the year's big events, Rick. So maybe we should just cast our eyes back on some of the big news stories.
I think people are waiting to see our, our, our three opinions on the, the review of the year.
Oh yeah. Yeah yeah yeah. Um, I should just give away this Eurythmics platinum-
Platinum disc-
Yeah!

-that we uh, we offered up in the first hour. Um, we were asking for the worst Christmas gifts you'd ever received and, uh, I want to give it to this guy because, I- I- well... it's, it's not like, you know, I'm sure it's fine but it's just something about it, which really amuses me, it's from Toby in London. He says, "When I was younger, I got a book about crude oil. I'd never expressed an interest in oil and certainly not crude oil."
Ricky laughs
But what I love is just, it's the parents. It's, it's thinking of that gift.
They were shopping. They were going, "Uh, what... what oil is it that Toby likes?"
Yeah.
"I don't- he - does he like oil?"
"It's olive oil, probably. I don't..."
"No, no, no, he thinks olive oil's sissy. What's that one that... he loves the spouting out of the ground one."
"Uh, I- crude oil?"
"Get him the book on crude oil, Mary."
Steve laughs
Unbelievable.

So Toby in London, you get the Eurythmics platinum disc, well done to you. Also in this hour we've got some Kylie collectibles to give away. So we'll probably do Rockbusters and the lucky winner of that gets those. Um, but I was just, I was just going through the papers of course, and it's the New Year's honours list today. And, I imagine you're very excited about that, Karl.
New Year's, New Year's honours, and all that?
Yeah, you familiar with that? When people get knighthoods and OBEs?
I, I, I've heard about it.
Sir Tom Jones
You've got call him Sir Tom now. Are you pleased with that? Do you think Tom Jones deserved it?
Erm... well, they sort of chuck 'em out to anyone now, don't they?
Steve laughs
So if he wants one, let him have one.
Do they?
Is it-
Well... it's just, I mean, the way I saw it was, um, like, you know, the Queen used to give them out to people who, er, you know, did, did like, big things, like killing dragons and all that.
Yeah.
Steve laughs
That was a while - that was a while ago, but yeah yeah yeah yeah.
Now it's, you know, from dragon killers to, sort of, Joe Pasquale.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Yeah. I see what you mean. Yeah. You went in the jungle with Ant and Dec. Here's a,
Here's an OBE.

Some people, uh, actually send them - I mean, famously, some rock stars and, and big names, they sometimes give their awards back or they refuse to accept the knighthood. If it was offered to you, Rick, would you accept it, your OBE, or your...?

You see, look, I, I, I don't know because one, I know it's, it's, it's sort of like not a cool thing and I don't know if you should align yourself with that, that sort of thing or whatever, and whether you're a monarchist or not, which I, I'm sort of in different really, um, ah, but I would feel rude.
Yes. I know what you mean.
It's, it's, it's, you know, after we won the Golden Globes, an interviewer said,

"Do you think you'll get a knighthood?" And I went, "Oh, I don't want a knighthood," and they said, "Why not?" I said, "You can't do anything with it." I said, "In the olden days, you could ride a, a, a white horse along and, and have a big sword. Nowadays you can just put it on your headed notepaper, so.
Yeah, yeah.
And I said something like, um, I'd rather have a name like Don Gervaisie.
Steve laughs
And the headline was 'Ricky wants to join the mafia.'
Steve laughs
Which I think is a bit harsh. Oh, I've been invited to the palace a couple times. I think about-
Whoa, hang on, what? What do you mean?
I've been invited to the palace about three times-
Why?
Um-
Can I just point out for people who don't know who I am?
I collaborate with Ricky-
Ricky giggles
-on everything except, uh, his stand-up comedy, which I suspect was not the reason you were getting invited to the palace.
No.
Because it's a little bit bawdy. A litle bit blue.
Or for my work on Flanimals.
Yeah, for your children's-
Ricky imitates the Queen
"Please get him along. I love the Mung Ungler."
Steve laughs
"I love that Mung Ungler."
So I should just point out that I've co-written both The Office and Extras and and, um-
Yeah.
-yet I've never had an invite from the palace.
Yeah, but I think the Queen knows who's the, who's the main one, who's the driving force.
Mm.
You know. You know. Anyway, right. So I get this thing through, the first time. I thought, "Oh, oh, I, I can't. I, I can't go."
Why couldn't you go?

Well, I, I dunno. I don't know. The second time it came through, and I said to Jane... it was like six o'clock, right. And I said, "Oh, shall we go?" And um, it was very exciting, but I felt a bit funny just going along to the palace, right? And I-
Sorry, who was it - just be you and Jane and Prince Philip and the Queen, was it? That was-
Well no, there was about, I don't know, I think there was about eight.
Right.
There was about eight people, right. The usual people.
Presumably they needed some extra people for Pictionary.
The usual. Me, Salman Rushdie.
Yeah.
David Bowie.
Yeah. Sure.
Right, um. Uh, an-
Well you're aligning yourself in the company of geniuses I notice there.
No, no. I'll tell you something about Salman Rushdie later. Um, and
I said to Jane, I said, "We could go for an hour." She went, "It's not the sort of thing that you can turn up for an hour with a, with a-
Yeah!
-some Liebfraumilch!"
It's not someone - it's not your boss's barbeque at the weekend!
Pop in. "I've got some other people to see, I'm seeing Tony Blair later. Anyway, cheers, Liz." But anyway the thing that came through was, "I will be attending / not be attending." Right?
Yeah.
And I thought that was just too harsh to send back, "I will not be attending."
Yeah.
So I, I, there was a number at the Master's House and I called him up and he went-
Ricky imitates posh voice
"Hello." And I said, "Hello, it's Ricky Gervais here, um

I got an invite, um, for the palace, I won't be able to attend. I said, I thought it was a little bit harsh to just send back "I will not be attending." He said, "How delightfully polite of you to call."
Steve laughs
Was it Roger Moore?
I don't know! But I went, "That's no worries," and he said, "Oh that's no trouble, thank you so much for calling." I bet no-one calls him.
Yeah.

I bet he doesn't get a look in and it was really- I was so glad I called and didn't just send back "I will not be attending." But listen, keep inviting me, 'cause I mean if it's right for my diary, I'd love to come along and have a mooch around. Seriously.
Yeah, see what's going on up there.
Yeah. So uh - Salman Rushdie, right, this is a, a funny story, so, I've met him a few times now.
Now he's out and about.
Sure.
He's never home.
No.
I bet his house is a mess.
Yeah.
Right. Um, uh, it was just after the, the first, um, series of The Office went out. I got invited to this, um, uh, thing, uh, uh, I'd met Jonathan, actually. I'd met Jonathan Ross on this-
Ok.

-on this show. And um, uh, we were talking about being Bowie fans. I'd never met him before. And he said, "Well I'm interviewing Bowie for this special, come along." And I went along, and there was Bowie, my hero. It was amazing. A couple of big celebrities in the audience, one of them was just Salman Rushdie, and uh, Greg Dyke

Who was, uh, head of BBC then, said to me, said, "I'm a Bowie fan, do you wanna go and meet him?" and I went, "Uh, okay." All right. So we went down. So it's me, Greg Dyke, right, and Salman Rushdie, going, "I'm chatting to Bowie." I went to the pub the next day, with my mate, and he said, "What did you do last night?"
Steve laughs
And I said, "Nothing." Because I couldn't say, "I was hanging out with David Bowie, Greg Dyke and Salman Rushdie. Why? What did you do?"
Steve laughs
I just said, "Nothing."
If uh, you can name every, uh, celebrity that Ricky has mentioned in the last link...
Ricky laughs
Uh, who he spent time with, then you can win yourself a prize. Um, perhaps a signed copy of, uh, Extras. Um, for which he got invited to the palace and I didn't.
Ricky laughs
Uh, 882921 if you can name every name that Ricky Gervais dropped.
[unintelligible]
Ryan Adams - Wonderwall
Rick, as you know, I absolutely love a good cover version. I think that a cover version, if it's done really well, can not only match the original, it can sometimes even better it.
I totally agree.

And I think that, that's Ryan Adams' version of Wonderwall. And I think, you know, much as I love Wonderwall, it almost reinvests it with a new beauty, and a new majesty that perhaps we've forgotten about because the other song is so overplayed.
No taking it away from Noel.
Oh not at all.
But that-
It's almost kind of reinvented it.
It's beautiful. Absolutely beautiful. Great song anyway.
And that's what's weird, really, 'cause you've done that and that's kind of what I've done.
With Rockbusters.
Right.
I've taken something-
Well, you've taken Blockbusters and changed one word.
-and sort of made it better.
No, not really.
Karl makes a noise of disagreement
Because those are real clues that work.
Karl makes another noise of disgreement
Yours are the ramblings of a madman.
Steve laughs
You don't really understand what the word cryptic means-
A little bit strong.
-it's more - this should be called, what am I thinking?
Well.
What am I thinking?

We should just introduce the idea of Rockbusters to people who didn't hear it last week. Um, now I'm trying to think of some classic ones. Do you remember there was the now, what was it, the, the, the, the West-
The Jamaican fella.
-Jamaican fella.
Jamaican fella spinning, sprin, uh, spinning a, um, a fish round his head.
That was De Trout Spinners.
De Trout Spinners.
And he tried to make it sound-I mean, it doesn't work.
You have to speak in a Jamaican accent.
It doesn't work-
And say De Trout Spinners.
Well, they wouldn't, they wouldn't say De Trout.
They'd say Detroit.
Steve laughs
Detroit Spinners.
So it doesn't work there. So that's the stupid 'Wet Knee Houston'.
Yeah.
No one called Wet Knee Houston.
Yep.
So, uh-
So you need to basically crawl inside Karl's head and figure out what's going on in there if you want to win these. We've got some Kylie collectibles for Rockbusters.
The good thing about crawling into Karl's head is there is a  lot of room.
There's plenty of room.
This-yeah.
It's very much like when God created the Earth. You can just fill it up with any
Thing. Um.
Ricky laughs
Yeah.
Birds... So, um, your Rockbusters clues this week then, Karl.
Alright, so as always, you know, we did it last week. There's three-
What can you win, though?
The Kylie Collectibles.
Brilliant. Excellent. Shall we throw in some stuff of ours? Just... to try and get rid of?
If we've got any tat-
That we got for free, yeah. Extras, Flanimals, etc.
Also other junk lying around in the office.
Yeah.
Alright. So then, uh, three clues. You text in with the answers. You win the stuff. Alright? First one. First clue. Uh... the initials of the band or the artist...
Right.
Are FF.
Right?
FF. Okay.
FF and the sort of cryptic-
Well I know it already.
And the cryptic - well, don't ruin it. And the cryptic clue... I've got snails, croissants, and baguettes in me palm, right? What's, what's, what's going on there?
Oh, no, I don't know it.
Alright. There's the clue.
Say that again.
I've got snails, croissants, and baguettes in me palm. Huh, that's weird.
Ricky and Steve laugh
FF. Right. FF. What's the band or the artist?
The clue changes every so slightly every time.
I know.
Right, the next one. Uh.
Me granny is, is taken a penalty. She better get the ball in the back of the net. NM. Artist or a band. NM. That's an old artist, by the way.
Give it to us again.
NM. Me granny's taking a penalty-
I've got it!
-she better get in the back of the net.
It's a good one.
Okay.
It's a good one.
Alright.
That's, that might be his best ever.
Wow!
There you go, right. And the last one, this is, this is a tough one. But you know, they know how it works.
That, that - well, when he says, "Tough," he means, "Doesn't work."
Yes.
Uh...
Does not work. Repeat.
This does not work. Go on.

And we were going to have a quick, um, assessment of the year's events because it's been a tumultuous year in many ways, Rick. Um, you know, some, some, some steps forward. Um, I'm sure you'll agree with the uh, ban on fox hunting.
Uh, absolutely. And I really can't believe it took to 2005. I really... and then people moaning, "We can't go and hunt foxes." "Oh, why not? You can't go and have a fox
Ripped to pieces! Oh, what do you want to do instead?"
I never understood it because it was... people getting up in arms and it's, it's a sport for them.
It is a sport.
It's a, er, a game.
Yeah.
So, it's like, you can't play Yahtzee anymore-
I know.
-you've gotta Guess Who? Well, alright. I'll, I'll cope.

All this rubbish about, "Oh, well, you know, it's what foxes do." Oh, is it? Oh right, but why do YOU like it? Why do - you wouldn't want a robot fox, because you wanna see blood. My brother-in-law was doing this job. He's a driver and he went to this sort of really posh school, and he was talking to someone, They were into fox hunting and stuff. And he said, "I don't agree with um," - just chatting, he said- "I don't agree with fox hunting." They went, "Oh why,
"are you a vegetarian?" He went. "No, I eat meat." They went, "You eat meat but you don't agree with hunting?" He went, "Why, do you eat fox?"
Yeah. Fair Point.
I mean it is such a ridiculous argument.
Are you pleased with that ban, uh, Karl?
What, sort of? I- I tho- I don't think, you know, we should sort of, hurt any animals, should we?
I totally agree.
And, sort of, you know, respect their place and that. I mean, I've, I, I went on holiday once, right? Went into the sea, right? Was only up to me knees, right? Got stung by a jellyfish, right?
Sure.
And what I mean is, like, you know, the sea, that's
Someone else's territory, innit?
Right.
And I could have had a moan.
Steve laughs
But you thought, "Fair enough."
But I was like, "Well I shouldn't be here."
Whereas if you went home and you were watching telly and the jellyfish came at you-
I'd say, "What's going on?"
Steve laughs
You would, wouldn't ya? You would say, "What's going on," wouldn't ya?
Ricky cracks up

You definitely would! If a jellyfish came out from behind your telly and clamped onto your face, you'd go, "Suzanne, what's going on? What's, what's a jellyfish doing? I don't go into the sea!" But it's like when they, um, that, that bloke that climbed into a polar bear cage and got eaten-
Steve laughs
-And there was a thing about, have the polar bear, put down. No, don't have the polar bear put down. You
Took him from the ice caps, popped him in a zoo, right?
Yeah.
That's his house now. He didn't want to be there.
Yeah. Yeah.
Right. And then someone climbed in. I love it when a, a matador gets gored to death. I love it! Because the bull didn't want to fight.
Happy new year.
Ricky laughs

Um, but also uh, also this year, of course, we've had the, uh, the gay civil marriages or the civil ceremonies, I'm not entirely sure yet what this is. Do we loosely call it gay marriage, just for the sake of ease?
No it, well it's just uh, it's a, officially a, A civil marriage, isn't it? They're not saying it's a marriage as such because I don't know...
I don't know if the church'll acknowledge it or not. I'm not sure.
I suppose if-
We've got enough vicars listening. Phone in.
They can let us know.
Let us, let us know. Yeah.
Um, but I don't know if you read it, I read it in the paper the other day-
But the church is gonna look nice, innit? The flowers are going to look brilliant.
Really good.
Aren't they?
Ricky giggles

But, um, uh, I don't know if you read the other day that um, I was pleased to read that John Inman, Mr Humphries from Are You Being Served has, has just um been involved in his civil ceremony with his longtime partner.
Whoa, whoa. John Inman's gay?!
Steve laughs
Yeah, no, I know! Stunning, isn't it?
I know, unbelievable. I do like it when, uh, uh one of those sort of people that are, so obviously gay,
They come out.
Yeah.
After like years and years, like Elton John.
Yeah.
Comes out goes, "Actually, I've got some news. Sit down, mate, just sit down, I've got some news for you." "Oh, hello, Elton. Like your new pink tracksuit by the way."
Steve laughs
Yeah.
"That's what I want to talk to you about."
Yeah.
"I am actually gay." And they all have to go, "You're joking! No!"
Yeah, they've gotta fake it.
"No way!"
Like when someone knows there's a surprise party for them and they've got pretend that they... "Oh my god, I can't believe it!"
Ricky laughs
But um...
Yeah, so what have we had? We've had, uh... it is a, a year of disasters, which is, uh... It does seem worse this year. I don't know. Maybe I'm
Htitting that age where I think there was like, it was nicer before. But it did, it was was a year of disasters, wasn't it?

It's been terrible. Well, we've had the, obviously Hurricane Katrina and the tsunami and the earthquake and things, and, um, and it's obviously been terrible and we don't want to be, to be flippant about that. But the only time I was praying for a natural disaster of Biblical proportions was when I was watching Celebrity love Island.
Ricky cracks up

And it, and it never happened. And some of the dregs of humanity on that show. I mean I don't know if you saw it, but Paul Danan is a joy because he's a mental case. And I'm saying that, I don't know if that's libelous but, I mean, if anyone's seen the
What did you say?
I said he was a mental case.
Yeah, that's pretty libelous, I think he could sue you there.
Okay, well I'll take that back.

Take that back, he's not a mental case. I mean, let's face it-- before you say anyone is stupid or a mental case, do the old binary sort, are they madder and thicker than Karl? If not, I think you ... you know...
That means I can ever accuse anyone of being stupid.
Ricky laughs
He was talking about lady Isabella Hervey and he went, I love Lady Isabella Hervey. Because thing is like, she-- she doesn't like books, and I don't like books.
Brilliant. They've got so much in common then.
Something in common is something that they don't do together.
I love the idea that people were sitting around just praying for a big wind
Just a big wind
And the only big wind was from Rebecca Loos.
In the Ghetto. By Elvis. That's one of the 10 songs that Karl likes.
Yes.
I mean, I've never met anyone who is... I don't know, so underwhelmed by music and the plethora of..
No, I do like it
But you said about-- when I first got my iPod, which I absolutely love, okay? And I was downloading-- I said I've got 10,000 songs on it, he said: "What do you need that many for?"

He said, I like a Walkman. He said, you know, you're going for a walk, "Well, how long's the walk?" When do you need 10,000 records? And he was trying to work out how many he would put on and he got about 7.
And what do you like? You only like songs with a story?

Mainly. A song that, you know, when you pop it on you go "Right, I'm going to listen to this for however long it is" and you've got to check it all out. You can't just turn it off and fade it off, because you've got to hear how the story ends.

But how many times can you hear the same story? I mean, it's a great tune but it's not because it's a story, it's because the lyrical content apart from the story aspect and the beautiful tune, and the way he sings and the production--
No, it's not about
Otherwise you've got to go: "Ehm, a bloke, born on the wrong side of the tracks, tries to nick a car, gets shot."

Yeah, but think about what you just said. And what I'm saying is, if you get up to "he was born on the right or wrong side of the tracks" whatever, I'll turn it off now, you'd be going "I wonder what happened to him"
Ricky sighs
So you listen to it all
What other songs are there with a story?
There's one from Johnny Cash, when his nicking a car from a factory.
What happens there? I don't remember that song.
He works in a car factory and every day he's going "Right, I'll nick little bolt." Right? Then he nicks a wing mirror and thinking, he nicks a gear stick and that.
So if you've got seven songs that you like, I mean it must be-- What's your favorite? What's your favorite song of all time?
But how could you do that because you haven't heard how it ended now, you see? I've just told you there what he was doing...
Because you probably got it wrong.
I haven't
I assume everything you say it's probably wrong.
There you go then, you will never know. And that will annoy you now. So... Other songs I like, Rod Stewart: Killing a Georgie
Oh yeah, that's your favorite song isn't it?
That's good.
Cause it's...
What's the story there?
Just about a little gay fella, goes to New York, because that's like... I think it was in the 70s when like, you know if you were gay and that, New York was brilliant.
Yeah.
That was like, you know where they all went and stuff. Had a good life there. His Dad, didn't... I think his dad kicked him out or something.
No, you... I'm sure you're thinking of Smalltown Boy by Bronski Beat. I'm sure you had all these mixed up--, just because it's another little gay fella. As you call them.
Anyway, goes he goes to New York
He goes to New York

[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

This is mental.
Did they re-freeze the ice caps? What? Tell me... You've got to be... [inaudible]

WHERE?!
It floated off.

Oh, I can't be bothered.

He's got to realize that if we didn't ramble we wouldn't have a show.
This is it.
This is what we do - when you've got Karl opposite you, there's nothing else - it can't be done.

Put on a CD if you don't want to hear the rambling. These people who email into a radio station and go "play some ELO!" - well put a CD on. You must have the greatest hits of ELO if you want to hear it so much - why are you phoning up a radio station?
Well, I think it's more the dedication, you know, it's just wants to tell his wife...
Yeah but, you know...
You know...
Do it on a better show.
What, than this?

Yeah, it's probably any... uhh, in the second hour we've got a more stuff to give - the THIRD hour, my goodness me, we've already got through the second hour. We got more stuff to give away, we've got... what else have we got? We've got Monkey News
Oh Monkey News! That's what the nation's waiting for.

Oh, jesus.

We've got a Red Hot Chili Peppers, Platinum disc.
Brilliant, only platinum on this show.
Yeah.
None of your gold muck.
Absolutely. We need some kind of quiz question, because we want to make sure that only a Red Hot Chili Peppers fan gets this merchandise.
Okay. Um, what about something like - famously, they were photographed with a sock over their what?
Anyone can get that,
That's too easy, isn't it? Notice how I was all coy? I didn't want to say that - why didn't I just say? Oh no because I was asking the question.
Yeah.
Wouldn't I, ya? What would people phone in do you think? They'd have to say... Although that's no good - it was their... We know what it was. It was over their. What would I say? On Radio 2?
John Thomas?

John Thomas - over their... They'll think that's probably a member of the band. What do you say when you go to the doctor with your... trouble? Look okay I know what we're talking about. We're talking about a man's parts downstairs that's what they popped a sock on.
Well if I went to a doctor I'd be honest. I'd just say "Excuse me doctor I've got a problem with my penis".
Wouldn't that make you laugh saying that? even to a doctor? even though it's the official term? Wouldn't you be...?
Well...
It's funny, isn't it - going to saying - because you never use that term.
No yeah, because it's so it's formal I suppose.
It's like you're trying to sort of like put on airs and graces which you're in the company of a doctor. What would you say?
What if they had a problem?
Yeah
I had to go to the doctor...
With your...
I probably won't go.
What do you mean?
I'd show it to Suzanne and say "is that normal?" -
Ricky laughs.
No I haven't. I've no I mean, I'm 32 right...
Why should she know necessarily?
No - just you know...
She's not a doctor and there's nothing about you that's normal. So I can only imagine...
No but you know what I'm like - I have, you know, Suzanne my girlfriend wants me to go to that Well Man Clinic - I said "ohh, no way". Unless I'm really ill.
Well should you should. You should get everything checked out.

The finger up the...

What's the, what's the funniest term for... no....

It was party time.
Anyway, all I'm saying...
He was, you know, hanging out with what's his name. McFly? It was brilliant.
So normally I just pick up on the stories that sort of made me go "oh that's quite interesting". Right. Two that stuck out for me in 2005.
Blind people not always using dogs now, they've got horses.
Well that's ridiculous, it's not true.
What are you talking about?
It is true.
What do you mean?
They're trying out, people - you know, they've got guide dogs and that?
Yes!
They're sort of saying "why stop there" they're giving them...
Well, do you know why? Because a dog....
You can't get a horse in the library.
Exactly. 'cos dogs, can go into Tescos with you and go around to visit your auntie, and sit at your feet. What do you do with a horse?
No, it just cuts out the middleman. If the horse knows where it's going - person gets on the back, off it goes.
Oh don't talk rubbish.
Where did you read this?!
From stories.
Where did you read this, yeah?
I've got a printed off. I can show it to you.
Oh so it's the internet. Of course it was the internet. Yeah, I mean, when will you learn?
But why is that such a mad idea?
Because you haven't got the whole idea, I bet it is something. I bet there's a grain of truth to it, right. But there's no way that they're going to be used like guide dogs. I mean, just think!
I'll look at the new story during the next song and we'll...
What else? What else? There must be another new story that's...
Yeah I did... there's another one.
Go on...
A fellow had a problem with the chicken. Wasn't lying enough eggs and that. He got an axe, put it next to its little house, that was living in. Panicked it a bit, laid loads of eggs.
Ricky laughs
How is that a major news story?
No, it's not major, but it's interesting isn't it?
What? Frightening a chicken into laying an egg?
Yeah.
And they're sort of the two things that...
That's the only two news stories that caught your attention.
That's amazing. I mean that am- plus monkey news. Obviously, every week you...,
Well.
You keep up-to-date with monkey news.
But what do you think about when when you are about that chicken? What what?

I don't think anything of it because it came from you. So you probably got something wrong, or it was a little fluff piece in a tabloid that just someone... they had a slow news day that day there, you know, there was...
Now rick, am I right in saying that karl himself made the news this year? Because wasn't it, right? That a friend of your girlfriend's had read about him. Apparently you were slagging off Cornwall.
Oh, yeah, yeah, my uh, my girlfriend's sister lives in Cornwall and you were the front, sort of story on them something, like the Western something or other edition, slacking off Cornwall.
Where you on about?
What have you been up to?
What have you said, what we said about Cornwall?
I haven't said anything. I like Cornwall.
Yeah, but you must have said something, or they wouldn't have... they mentioned Karl Pilkington.
You've been slacking it off apparently.
I love Cornwall, I love going there.
Have you ever said anything about it negative?
What was that thing? Oh, didn't you slag someone off in Mevagissey. You went into a pub in Mevagissey.
See.
Yeah, and he was 'airy, that was, that- that's that one fella. There was a, a sort of - I went in there and they're really friendly and everything in Cornwall.
Yeah-
If you're listening out there.
Don't creep.
No, but I like it. I'd, if I wanted to retire and that, early, that's where I'd go and live.
I wouldn't now.

But I went there, right, in this little place called Mevagissey, and went into a pub. And the woman behind the bar was all friendly and goin', it was at round Christmastime and she says, oh what we normally do is like have a fancy dress and stuff. She says here y'are, I'll show you some pictures, right? And she was going through, and it was a picture of someone there, and I said, God, what- you know, what's he come as? Look at him, he's well 'airy. And she said "oh, he just works behind the bar, he wasn't dressed as anything." And he came out, round the corner, 'airy fella. But- but there's no way that made the paper.
Have you said said anything else negative about him?
When was the last time you were in Cornwall?
It was- we took someone for a wedding present. We took someone on holiday there, a week.
Yeah.
Um, there was a fella on the beach who, uh, he worked in one of them huts. You know how they sell deck chairs and stuff.
Oh yeah, yeah.

And I think that's a pretty nice job, especially in summer, innit. The sun's out, you're sat there, all you've got to do is talk to people. Say, "what you want, two deck chairs, there you go, no problem, see you later." But this fella, right? I kept- I went in there and got the chairs, took 'em back. He's being really moody. He said, "oh, see you got a lot of sand on 'em." I said, well there's loads of it out there. It's not a surprise that it's stuck- and he had a bit of a moan at me, and I don't know if I've ever mentioned that, sort of, openly.
Well,maybe he recognized you,
But that isn't a diss, that's one person, innit.
If you're from Cornwall and you've got any reason to dislike Karl-
But there's not many people live in Cornwall, it's a very small community, I mean no wonder they don't want to be part of us, with people like you slagging 'em off.
I love Cornwall, got nothing against it.

So do I, I think Cornwall's beautiful. You're an idiot. Don't- don't- don't- Anyone in Cornwall, do not judge the rest of the nation by Karl Pilkington, it's not fair. I sometimes wonder if- imagine if he's the one that archaeologists dig up in a million years' time.
Yeah.
And find some of his notes and they play- they measure the head and everything, and then some of the ramblings that he did, you know?
Or if an alien comes down, it would just be him that they bump into.
That would be a- just our luck, wouldn't it.
Well I tell you what though, talking of like education and that-
Go on.

I'm not, I know I'm not the brightest bloke knocking about and that, right? But I treated myself the other day to a new mobile right? And, you know, going through it, getting used to it, getting used to, how to send texts and all that, and you know, the predictive text?
Yeah.
So if you send a text, you type it in, and that sort of guesses what you're going to write out.
Yeah.

And it's new, so it doesn't really know me yet. Right? I was sending a text to someone. Say something like, I ain't got a clue or something, right? Wrote ain't, right, A-I-N-T, looked up to- at the screen to make sure that it'd written it, right? That had written up "biotechnology."
WHAT? What?
That had predicted that I was going to use the word biotechno- I am never going to use that word, ever.
What? "I ain't got a clue?"
No, "ain't," A-I-N-T.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Was it? Ugh... Shall we have some real news?
Well... what is that?
I-I'm just...I'm dumbfounded by that monkey news.
But it's all there, Steve.
Okay, well I'll I'll I'll- I'm going to give it a full assessment.
Let's see if-there's the news coming up. See if there's any stories like that in this. Right. On 88 to 91 FM. This is Radio 2 from the BBC.
Thanks for listening.

synopsis.description: Ricky describes Karl for new listeners
Karl will be giving a sermon to revive the forgotten religion of Christianity
Karl gave Suzanne a second-hand camera for Christmas
Karl's best present ever, the Sinclair Spectrum
Eight-year-old Karl is sick from stress
Ricky, Jane, Karl, and Suzanne go to see The Woman in Black
Ricky imagines squeezing Karl's head in a vice at a nice Italian place
Steve hates noisy people at the cinema
Karl thinks you can chat through a film if it has subtitles
Karl begins his sermon
Rockbusters is coming
Monkey News vs Adam and Eve
Steve finally gives away the Eurythmics platinum disc
Ricky has been invited to the palace. Steve hasn't.
Rockbusters
Fox hunting has been banned
Gay marriage
Karl is happier than Einstein
Blind people are riding horses now.
A farmer frightened a chicken into laying more eggs by putting an axe near it's little house.
Karl made the papers slagging off Cornwall.

Apparently people do use "guide horses" but only [very small ones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guide_horse) that can fit in Tescos:

This could have been the Western Morning News (Sunday edition?)
